title: The science of why you have great ideas in the shower

last_post.content:
TIL there's a technical name for why ideas happen in the shower: the "default mode network" is a pattern of brain activity, measurable using fMRI, that happens when we're unfocussed. When the brain goes into idle mode (reduced activity), this part of the brain actually becomes *more* active. What does the default mode network do? Research is ongoing, but part of it definitely seems to be making connections, which is associated with curiosity and creativity.

More here: https://www.nationalgeographic.co.uk/history-and-civilisation/2022/08/the-science-of-why-you-have-great-ideas-in-the-shower

every paragraph in this paper is blowing my mind https://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/fulltext/S1364-6613(22)00236-4 even as someone who already believed in the infinite variety of language, there are just so many deeply researched counterexamples to basically anything you think is universal (especially if you're using english as your basis for "universal")

title: Your Face Belongs to Us by Kashmir Hill: 9780593448564 | PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books

last_post.content: My book on facial recognition technology comes out on September 19! Over the last two years, I tracked down the tech's early pioneers, found the people fighting against its worst impulses, and dove into the history of Clearview AI, the start-up that first drew me into the topic with a radical person-finding app that giants in the field, including Google and Facebook, had deemed taboo. It feels real now because there's a release date and a preorder button: https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/691288/your-face-belongs-to-us-by-kashmir-hill/

title: Attributed Question Answering: Evaluation and Modeling for Attributed Large Language Models

last_post.content:
I think attribution is pretty important (I just helped write a paper about it!). Of course Yoav is right that in human writing we usually add sources long after we’ve decided what we want to say. But for most use cases, it seems like a good idea to hold LMs to a higher standard. Anecdotally, i’ve found that non-experts often think ChatGPT “must be” doing search, even though it’s not.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08037

title: ‘Self-healing’ Roman concrete could aid modern construction, study suggests

last_post.content:
Turns out the key to solving the mystery of why Roman cement lasts longer than modern cement... was to stop underestimating ancient people.

"...samples of Roman concrete contain small lumps known as lime clasts that are not found in modern structures.

While these have previously been explained as arising from poor mixing of the mortar or other errors, the team suspected there could be other reasons."

https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/jan/06/self-healing-roman-concrete-could-aid-modern-construction-study-suggests

title: Banned in the USA: The Growing Movement to Censor Books in Schools

last_post.content:
Was just doing research for a book I #amwriting and discovered that in the U.S., over 1600 #books were banned in school libraries in 2022 -- as compared to just 175 being "challenged" in 2015 (books that are challenged are rarely banned, according to the American Library Association, so the numbers of banned books that year were much lower).

In 2022, 41% of books were banned for LBGT content. 40% had BIPOC characters.

Citations:
2022: https://pen.org/report/banned-usa-growing-movement-to-censor-books-in-schools/

2015: https://www.ala.org/advocacy/bbooks/frequentlychallengedbooks/statistics/2015infographiclong

#Zotero & Mastodon tricks:
1. Bc Mastodon is using standard HTML, Zotero is able to recognize any DOIs in your current timeline & import the related works into your Zotero library:
Right-click on the Save to Zotero icon in your browser and select "Save to Zotero (DOI)"
2. Did you know you can add individual Mastodon posts with metadata to Zotero when you're looking at a single post view, e.g. by clicking on the timestamp (the URL will look sth like https://fediscience.org/@adam42smith/109639860471806025 )

10 years ago I wrote an ebook meant for designers and builders of #ToolsForThought, introducing thinkers they might not have met in engineering classes (e.g., Elinor Ostrom, Walter Ong) and sketching out the coevolution of humans, our ways of thinking, and our thinking tools, languages, alphabets, print, etc. Free PDF

http://rheingold.com/texts/Mind_Amplifier.pdf

@aparrish We see related problems in clinical #neurology, where our diagnostic criteria for aphasia assume English structure. E.g., one diagnostic criterion for semantic dementia is "surface dysgraphia"--improper regularization, like writing "yacht" as "yot." But this criterion relies on English's orthographic opacity, and wouldn't appear in languages like Spanish, Korean or Russian with more regular orthography.

Here's a fascinating paper by my colleague Boon Lead Tee on dysgraphia in Chinese-speakers with primary progressive aphasia: https://doi.org/10.1212/wnl.0000000000200350. Because Chinese writing is so different from English, these disorders manifest in really interestingly different ways--some analogous to presentations in English, others entirely distinct. Anyway, a challenge for cross-cultural diagnosis and management...
